questionListItems.title: Is there any haze management plan?

answer.body: Yes, OBS is in alignment with MOE’s haze management plan. During haze period, OBS will monitor the air quality via the National Environment Agency (NEA)'s Haze information. In the event of a haze situation that impacts the students’ participation, MOE and OBS will provide updates to schools. MOE & OBS will reference requirements and standards from national agencies and apply them accordingly.

questionListItems.title: Is OBS well prepare or train in medical treatment for insect, snake or marine creature attack?

answer.body:
OBS instructors have undergone rigorous training, skills and safety certification such as the Wilderness Advanced First Aid course..

OBS has on-site medical centre staffed by Registered Nurses. Our instructors and nurses will treat minor ailments and injuries, and if a student requires further medical attention (e.g. doctor’s consultation), they will be sent to the nearest clinic or hospital.

 

In the event of medical emergency, OBS has access to a fleet of land and sea vehicles to support fast evacuation to emergency medical services such as an ambulance or A&E.

questionListItems.title: Are boys and girls separated during sleeping arrangements at OBS?

answer.body: Students will be sleeping in tents as the course is journey-based. Allocation of tents will be separated by gender within the campsite. Instructors will be camping in close proximity of the camping area.

questionListItems.title: Is there a doctor present on-site at OBS?

answer.body: There are no doctors stationed in OBS. In the case of minor ailments or injuries, students will be attended to by their Instructor. If needed, Instructors will refer the student to the OBS medical centre, staffed by Registered Nurses. If a student requires further medical attention (e.g. doctor’s consultation), they will be sent to the nearest clinic or hospital accompanied by an OBS staff.

questionListItems.title: Is it mandatory for all participants, including non-swimmers, to wear Personal Flotation Devices (PFD) during water activities at OBS?

answer.body: Personal floatation devices (PFDs) will be provided to all participants and it will be mandatory during water activities. The instructor will also take progressive approach which includes conducting water confidence test at shallow waters before moving on to deeper waters.

questionListItems.title: Are there wild animals during the camp? Will students be taught how to handle encounters with them?

answer.body:
Wildlife encounter may occur during the camp as our activities mostly take place in the outdoors.

Our instructors have gone through trainings on how to manage and react when encountering wildlife which they will share and guide students about them.

questionListItems.title: What is the procedure for students who wear spectacles, especially during water activities?

answer.body:
As per the packing list, students wearing spectacles or sunglasses are encouraged to bring spectacles bands to secure their spectacles and bring extra pair of spectacles where possible.

Securing spectacles or sunglasses during water activities is important to prevent them from getting lost or damaged. Here are some tips on how to secure them:

  1. Use an eyewear strap: Attach an eyewear retainer to the ends of the spectacles or sunglasses. These straps are typically made of neoprene or other water-friendly materials and can be worn around the back of the head or neck. They help keep the eyewear in place, even during active water activities.

  2. Choose a floating eyewear strap: Consider using a floating eyewear strap if there's a chance the eyewear could fall into the water. These eyewear straps have buoyant properties, ensuring that the spectacles or sunglasses stay afloat if they accidentally come off.

  3. DIY eyewear strap: Students may request for cotton twine from their instructors to DIY their own eyewear strap.

Even with the above precautions, accidents can happen. As part of their personal responsibility to care for own belonging, students are to be mindful of their eyewear during water activities and take additional steps to minimize the risk of loss or damage. As per the packing list, students wearing spectacles or sunglasses are also encouraged to bring extra pair of spectacles where possible.

questionListItems.title: If a child falls ill during the course, where should parents pick them up? Will it be at the school or OBS campsite?

answer.body: Depending on the campus which the student is allocated to, OBS will advise the parents of the pick-up location. In the case of minor ailments or injuries, students will be attended to by their instructor. If needed, Instructors will refer the student to the OBS on-site medical centre, staffed by Registered Nurses. If a student requires further medical attention (e.g. doctor’s consultation), they will be sent to the nearest clinic or hospital accompanied by an OBS staff.

questionListItems.title: Are there boats available 24/7 for evacuation of students in Pulau Ubin?

answer.body: There will be boat operating 24/7 during the course for emergency evacuation

questionListItems.title: Is there supervision provided for students while they sleep in the tents such as in case of an emergency?

answer.body:
Students will be sleeping in tents and in designated campsites as the course is journey-based. Instructors will be camping within close proximity of the camping area and can be alerted by students in event of any emergency.

Activities are expected to cease by 2200hrs and the instructors will conduct a last check before students turn in for each night.

questionListItems.title: What safety measures are implemented for students at OBS?

answer.body:
Parents can help make the course safer by providing comprehensive declaration of health and medical condition(s). This enables OBS to better support participants during the course.


Activities are carefully designed and constantly supervised by qualified and experienced full time OBS instructors who have undergone rigorous training and safety certification such as the Wilderness Medical First Responder course. An appropriate instructor to student ratio ensures safe monitoring can be done during activities.

OBS has an Operations Room that is manned throughout the course. A dedicated team adopts the elements of Command, Communication and Control to enable safety monitoring, effective coordination, management, and communication. There is a comprehensive emergency plan that includes protocols for medical emergencies or any unforeseen circumstances.


There are Medical Centre/Posts that are well equipped and operate throughout the course. The registered nurses who manned the medical centre/posts support instructors who are in the field to assess and provide appropriate treatment for injured or unwell participants.


OBS also works closely with agencies like Singapore Civil Defence Force and Police Coast Guard (Singapore Police Force) when emergencies or extenuating circumstances arise.

questionListItems.title: What happens if my child has her period during the Course? Can she still go through the water activities

answer.body: Your child can still participate in all activities as per usual. Female students who are expecting their period during the course should bring extra supply of sanitary pads and dark-coloured shorts/pants. Newspaper or extra plastic bags will be useful for the disposal of soiled sanitary pads. There is no requirement for them to take any medication to delay or postpone their menstruation cycle, unless otherwise stated by their doctor. Additionally, they can approach any female OBS staff for assistance during the course.

questionListItems.title: What is the duration of the monitoring period for unwell students at OBS' Medical Centre? When will OBS determine if a student needs to be sent to the hospital?

answer.body: Monitoring of conditions is applicable to non-medical emergency conditions only. In these cases, assessment and review is done hourly and up to 2 hours to determine if condition improves, otherwise, the student may be sent to an external medical clinic. If it is an emergency, OBS will send the student to the hospital immediately. Aside from Instructor’s assessment, the OBS medical team comprising of registered nurses may also assess the condition.

questionListItems.title: When will parents be notified if their child needs medical attention or is unwell?

answer.body:
At the first instance of receiving a report of an injury/illness, OBS will assess, manage, and monitor. Medical treatment will be given by the instructor and/or registered nurses for the well-being of your child.

You will be informed if your child requires further medical attention at a clinic or hospital. If, after a period of rest and monitoring, our nurses and Instructors assess your child to be fit to re-join the course, you will not be informed.

questionListItems.title: If there is a student from any group showing flu-like or acute respiratory infection (ARI) symptoms, will OBS stop activities for the entire school or the group that the student is in?

answer.body: During the course, unwell students will first be attended to by Instructors and place in the care of the OBS medical team to assess or monitor his/her condition. Instructors will continue activities with the group. Student with suspected acute respiratory infection (ARI) symptoms will be separated from the group as soon as possible and the OBS medical team will hold the student in designated isolation area that is available within each campus and perform ART testing. If the student’s results turn out positive, the rest of the students from the same watch will perform ART testing as a precautionary measure. OBS will inform the school, who will then inform the parent of the student who is tested positive, to pick up the student from OBS campus directly.
